title: 110_hr3850
content: The Act may be cited as the "Responsible and Effective Solutions for Children Using and Entering Online Services Act of 2007". Data relating to crimes of child exploitation is addressed in the Act. Section 227(b) of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 is amended to include new requirements for providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services to include reliable information in their reports related to child abuse. Providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services must include reliable information in their reports related to child abuse, excluding any identifying information of the person involved such as user IDs, email addresses, website addresses, or geographic location details like street addresses or phone numbers. Providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services must include reliable information in their reports related to child abuse, such as the type of content, dates and times of incidents, and accurate contact information if not registered with the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. Providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services must include reliable information in their reports related to child abuse. They are required to provide details such as the type of content, dates and times of incidents, and accurate contact information. Additionally, they are authorized to forward reports to designated agencies and officials for enforcement of State criminal law or to foreign law enforcement agencies. Foreign law enforcement agencies willing to reciprocally refer reports related to child pornography and exploitation to the United States must meet specific criteria. This includes being a signatory to the Council of Europe Convention on Cybercrime or a Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty with the U.S. and having a legal basis to use the materials for investigating violations of foreign laws similar to U.S. laws on child pornography. Foreign law enforcement agencies must meet specific criteria to refer reports related to child pornography to the United States. This includes having a legal basis to maintain materials in confidence and not being from a state that supports acts of international terrorism. The Attorney General is required to designate staff members to preserve evidence. The Attorney General designates staff at the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to issue preservation requests for records related to child pornography reports referred to Internet Crimes Against Children Task Forces. The Attorney General designates staff at the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to issue preservation requests for records related to child pornography reports referred to Internet Crimes Against Children Task Forces. This includes reports made to the Cyber Tip Line by the public or electronic communication service providers in cases of immediate danger or serious physical injury to a child. Enhanced immunity is provided to encourage reporting by providers of electronic communication services or remote computer services. This includes limited liability for any civil claim or criminal charge brought against providers for actions taken in good faith to comply with this section. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children can use the information obtained. Section 227(f) of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 is amended to authorize the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children to provide information related to combating child pornography to electronic communication service providers. This includes sharing images and relevant data reported to its Cyber Tipline for specific purposes, with providers required to use the information solely for designated purposes. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children is authorized to share information on combating child pornography with electronic communication service providers for specific purposes, including developing technologies and best practices for prevention and detection. SEC. 5. ADDITIONAL PROVISIONS. Section 227 of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 is amended to include state preemption regarding notification of child pornography online. Additionally, the Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress on the number of reported cases. The annual report must include the number of investigations, prosecutions, and convictions of crimes of sexual exploitation against children initiated by reports to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. The annual report must include details on investigations, prosecutions, and convictions of crimes of sexual exploitation against children initiated by reports to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children, such as descriptions of sentences, time taken for investigations, and results of investigations including reopened cases and ultimate outcomes. The Inspector General of the Department of Justice will provide an independent verification report to Congress and the public on the Attorney General's annual report regarding investigations of crimes of sexual exploitation against children. The Act and its amendments will become effective 180 days after enactment.
